body: @jihoonson - I am closing this pull request for now.
Ok, thanks.

I've done some more tests and updated the PR description. One thing related to Hadoop support is that this PR works with Hadoop 2.7.5 if S3NFileSystem is set to use. The below is a quote from Hadoop Wiki.

> Unmainteained: S3N FileSystem (URI scheme: s3n://)
> S3N is the S3 Client for Hadoop 2.6 and earlier. From Hadoop 2.7+, switch to s3a
>
> A native filesystem for reading and writing regular files on S3.With this filesystem is that you can access files on S3 that were written with other tools. Conversely, other tools can access files written using Hadoop. The S3N code is stable and widely used, but is not adding any new features (which is why it remains stable).
>
> S3N requires a compatible version of the jets3t JAR on the classpath.
>
> Since Hadoop 2.6, all work on S3 integration has been with S3A. S3N is not maintained except for security risks â€”this helps guarantee security. Most bug reports against S3N will be closed as WONTFIX and the text "use S3A". Please switch to S3A if you can -and do try it before filing bug reports against S3N.

If only new features are not being added to S3N, I think it's fine. But, if there are some bugs, using S3N for Hadoop 2.7 won't work. @b-slim do you have any idea about this?
Great! I'll take a look soon.

Is that issue fixed in 0.11 version? We encounter topN issues with the aggregation results in 0.11 version when multi-valued dimension is null and I am wondering whether is related to this bug or not.

Stelian

Hi zhangxinyu1,

thank you so much for pushing for this feature. I've been wanting this for a long time and tried to raise awareness for it. This feature is definitely needed. I don't even understand how one can do without it.
I read the comments from the previous proposal.
Let me add a few things to those.
* It was being said that the idea of such a mechanism isn't new and it was mentioned that Vertica has a similar feature named "projections". In Vertica, projections have the same number of rows as the original table. So same same but different. The actual prior art would be OLAP. Many databased call themselves OLAP although they are missing every feature of it. These derived datasources in OLAP terms are called cuboids. And yes, it DOES speed up queries and no it is NOT an option to just add more hardware to the query layer. We have a Druid cluster which is dramatically slow because we need to have many dimensions. If a user makes a wide query and trillions of rows need to be scanned, even a large Druid cluster will need minutes to complete that query. The current caching mechanisms will not help with that. How would I scale up the cluster? If a given query takes one minute to execute I would need to make my cluster 60 times bigger to get the query to subsecond latency.
It was being said that people are manually reindexing secondary datasources. However, this becomes quite unfeasible very quickly. How to make sure that query results are consistent?
This heavy lifting should be done by a database system for exactly that purpose that it then isn't required anymore for everyone using the database to do the heavy lifting.

@zhangxinyu1 as I already said, I have invested a lot of thought on bringing this feature to Druid already. I so far always referred to this feature as "Datasource Delegation". Lets stick our heads together to figure this out.
The query path isn't that difficult. One can indeed mix and match which of the many secondary databases to include within a query. That's the beauty of it. An incoming query could be rewritten such that 95% of the timeline of a given query could be covered by the best secondary database, then maybe another 4% is served by segments coming from a bigger secondary database and most likely there will alsways be some segments that have not been re-indexed to some secondary database yet and which therefore would still come from the master datasource.

The most difficult part is to keep track on a per segment granularty basis whether a secondary datasource is in syn with the master. Those timeranges that are not in sync are not elligible to querying.

For the query path, it would also be great if historical queries could contain segment lists coming from different datasources. A historical receive queries that the broker has already rewritten such that there is a list of segments contained in a historical's query. Looking at this segment list, each segment is referenced by its complete ID with the exception of the datasource that the segment belongs to. If one could improve the historical queries such that a list of segments could be passed where every segment also contains the datasource it belongs to, then historicals could already merge data across datasources. 
This would totally work: if the broker has determined that a secondary datasource B is up-to-date with master datasouce A for a given segment-granularity slot and therefore picks some segments form B while choosing segments from A for some other time-interval, then a historical could execute a query on both kinds of segments because everything is column-oriented.

Some months back I started implementing this feature but never completed it. 

There are other OLAP features that one could nicely layer on top of your proposed solution at a later time. For instance "cell materialization". I once posted a proposal for a different feature which then turned into a discussion of your feature. Perhaps you'd like to read up on it here: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/druid-development/delegation%7Csort:date/druid-development/Ij3gJjuD4nY/ryC_aCw7GQAJ
Is anyone able to solve this issue ? I encountered this while deploying Druid in Mumbai AWS region. There were no issues in Ireland region.

I had the same issue rahulsingh303, when setting druid up for test in a relatively small node (small in RAM) in a cluster, but changing druid.processing.buffer.sizebytes to 256 MB made it work for me.

Hi @bendrecm, I've been done several tests against several Hadoop versions on #5382, and S3A shouldn't work because of the version mismatch of `aws-java-sdk` between Hadoop 2.7 and Druid. AFAIK, using S3N is the easiest workaround if you don't much care about performance degradation. Or, if you want to use S3A, another possible workaround is building a customized `hadoop-aws.jar` which shades aws libraries, and using it. You can find which changes are needed [here](https://github.com/apache/hadoop/compare/branch-2.7.5...jihoonson:hadoop-aws-for-druid?expand=1).

BTW, would you elaborate more on `There were no issues in Ireland region.`? Was there no problem at all using S3A and Hadoop 2.7 with Druid 0.10.1?
S3A issue relates to #4841.
Ready for review.
@jon-wei @gianm : Can one of you please review this ?
Can't we target this for `0.12.0`?

Hi @gianm ,

Do you know if someone is working on "last aggregator at indexing time" ??

> Someone (possibly you) would have to make the last aggregators work at indexing time. This would probably involve a new column type (pair of timestamp + value) similar to how the variance aggregator works.

I'm interested in this feature .. and maybe I will be able to start the development.

Hi @samarthjain, I'll do my review today or tomorrow. Before that, I'd like to ask one question. Looks that a query context value decides pushing nested query execution or not. Does this mean all nested subqueries are pushed to historicals if the query is deeply nested?

@jihoonson - Currently, when the user sets the push nested query execution flag on the outermost query, then the broker executes the entire nested query on the historical nodes. The broker then merges the results returned by the historical nodes as usual except that in this case, the rows returned by historical nodes have the structure of the outermost part of the query.
Thanks. It sounds good for the first step. Will leave some comments soon!
I believe I addressed the review comments. The build failure seems to be unrelated to the datasketches extension.
I'm a bit stuck here, I can't run integration tests locally on docker-for-osx, and the failures are pretty much undiagnosable
Ok, I'm trying allowing it completely as an opt-in thing to see if it passes integration tests now.

I added more detail to the Google groups topic. In particular,

Kafka KIP-98 for transactions:

https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/KIP-98+-+Exactly+Once+Delivery+and+Transactional+Messaging

Look at section 5.2 of that KIP "5.2 WriteTxnMarkerRequest"

It's also mentioned in https://www.confluent.io/blog/transactions-apache-kafka/ (Search for "transaction commit markers").
I believe that using the Kafka 0.11 client (or newer) will make the problem go away.

Hi @ebolwidt, thanks for the research!

Are you interested in contributing a test case (one that fails today) along with a patch to upgrade us to Kafka 0.11? If it turns out that the upgrade is all we need, that's great and it sounds like we should just do it.
Interested but time-constrained. I'll look into it at home as work infrastructure doesn't allow me to run the docker-based integration testsuite.
@Fokko unlikely. 0.12 had a feature freeze a while ago. It should make the next cut though.
Enough time has passed, merging
I see 2 approvals, merging

@drcrallen i have expressed opinions that such major low-level change needs to have some on/off switch but looks like you have merged this anyway... I don't think that is the best option given the fact that this feature is not even tested in real-world cluster...

@b-slim I understand your concern. If you can help (pointers, suggestions) how to implement that on/off switch somewhat cleanly I would appreciate it and Iâ€™m wIlling to go through the effort of adding it. One thing that I was thinking of was to make â€˜setfadvisepossibleâ€™ public and initalization of the configuration turn it either on or off. Does such an initalization happen? Would such an update be acceptable and take away your concerns?

Another change I will make is to improve the write speed for large sequential files, this will use a little bit more memory but will give more consistent write speeds.
Looks like it has a problem in integration tests.

CLA was signed and submitted; I made one additional commit to address PR feedback (removed todo, better handling of short / invalid timestamps) but did not squash to make it easier to see what changed -- I can squash if desired.

@gianm this PR is going to be incompatible even if I return Exceptions to throws clauses at some places, because it removes `DataSegmentPuller`.

After some more digging I found https://serverfault.com/questions/870568/fatal-error-cant-open-and-lock-privilege-tables-table-storage-engine-for-use which was causing mysql containers to fail. I added `"storage-driver" : "aufs"` to the docker for mac daemon and am trying the integration tests again.

yay! I'm getting the same errors as integration tests now

@jihoonson looks like using `aufs` storage is really important for docker on mac for integration tests. Don't know a good way to record that

@drcrallen hmm that's odd. I'm using `overlay2` for docker on mac and integration tests work well. And `aufs` looks not default anymore because of some performance issues (https://docs.docker.com/storage/storagedriver/aufs-driver/). Are you using docker-machine?

Underlying problem was `StatisticsHandler` is a wrapper, so you have to supply the underlying handler to call. I added it as the main handler to the jetty server, with the chain of other handlers as the delegate

It might be a red herring, though. So I wouldn't spend too much time on it unless others report a similar problem with integration tests.

Thanks for the feedback @jihoonson. I will address it in my next commit. Can you point me out as to how should I go about writing tests for this feature? I looked at GroupByQueryRunnerTest and I couldn't find an easy way of mocking the push down behavior. I essentially need a way to mimic that the nested query is getting executed on the historical nodes, and then the outer most query is operating on the results obtained after merging the results returned by the historicals. Would it make sense to instead use Druid SQL and write tests in something like CalciteQueryTest?
@samarthjain I think you can check out `GroupByLimitPushDownMultiNodeMergeTest` for an example of testing that kind of merging
@jon-wei thanks. It looks a good example to test merging.
@b-slim can you please include examples of when 64 vs 32 made a difference, and also record the impact in size and performance for switching from float to double?
LGTM, I'll merge after docs, the merge will auto-squash

I was working on some batch ingestion stuff using supervisor, but suddenly I changed my mind to not use supervisors anymore. I just didn't want to throw it away.

This seems like a relatively minor feature to require a DB migration for.

And an automatic migration is potentially problematic for the reasons in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/5315#discussion_r165440434.

What about adding the column to new tables, like we do here, but for old tables, detecting if it's there and then disabling this feature if it's not there?

I re-ran the tests. I agree didn't look related to this PR.

About documentation,

> I know it is not enough. I think the goal is to restructure the page about the datasketches extension, which currently talks about the Theta sketches only, but the extension already includes the Quantiles sketches module as well. And I have new HLL sketch aggregator module to submit after this one.

Created a PR so that emitter failures don't lead to query failures https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/5484 . Root cause in HTTPEmitter still needs to be identified and fixed

Makes sense. See also work-in-progress https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-1861 and https://github.com/julianhyde/calcite/tree/1861-spatial. We recognize queries with ST_DWithin and convert them to use materialized views on Hilbert curves. There are several ways to say the same thing using the OpenGIS function set (e.g. ST_DWithin vs ST_Buffer), so over time the rules will grow. Maybe Druid will end up using similar rewrite rules.

Would it make sense for Calcite to have some utility functions or rules that projects like Druid could use to help convert GIS functions into spatial filters? Or do you think the usages going to end up being too different?
